data.title: 21 castles and castle-like buildings throughout Pennsylvania
data.meta_description: Complete with spires and turrets and great halls, here are some of castles -- or, at least, castle-like structures -- that you can visit throughout the state.
data.text:
You don’t need fairy dust, a magic wardrobe or a giant eagle to find a castle in Pennsylvania. Complete with spires and turrets and great halls, here are some of castles — or, at least, castle-like structures — that you can visit throughout the state.

Photograph by Nicolas Raymond on Flickr. CC BY 3.0 US

Monument to the 12th and 44th New York Infantry regiments in Gettysburg

Where: You can find the monument at latitude 39.7912900 and longitude -77.2370200, according to the National Park Service. It's located in Gettysburg.

The "castle-like" monument to the 12th and 44th New York Infantry regiments has 440-feet-tall tower and an interior chamber with bronze tablets memorializing the soldiers, according to the nonprofit organization Gettysburg Foundation.

Gen. Daniel Butterfield, who was once the regimental commander of the 12th New York regiment and the first brigade commander of the 44th New York regiment, designed the monument. He was also the army’s Chief of Staff at Gettysburg and the composer of the bugle call “Taps.”

Photograph by Jon-Mark Davey on Flickr. CC BY-SA 2.0.

Buhl Mansion in Sharon

Where: The mansion is located at 422 E. State St. in Sharon, according to its website.

Construction on the Buhl Mansion started in 1890 and was completed in 1896 for a total of $60,000, according to the mansion's website.

Fulfilling a promise to his mother-in-law, steel magnate Frank H. Buhl built the “castle” for his wife Julia Forker. Youngstown architect Charles Owsley designed the mansion. Today, Donna Winner managers the Buhl Mansion as a guesthouse and a spa.

Bryn Athyn Cathedral in Bryn Athyn

Where: The cathedral is located at 900 Cathedral Road in Bryn Athyn, according to its website.

The Bryn Athyn Cathedral adopts at least two different styles, according to its website. Its main building is Gothic and its northern and southern buildings are Romanesque. It was constructed between 1913 and 1928, but work on its stained glass windows and interior decoration continued into the early 1940s.

The Bryn Athyn Cathedral is the “central place of worship for the Bryn Athyn Church and a gathering place for members of the New Church throughout the world,” according to its website.

Braddock Carnegie Library in Braddock

The Braddock Carnegie Library was built in 1888 in the eclectic medieval style, according to its website. It had a number of recreational facilities, including a billiard table on the first floor and a bathhouse in the basement. A 1893 addition included a 964-seat music hall, a gymnasium, a swimming pool and a two-lane bowling alley.

William Halsey Wood built the library, which Andrew Carnegie dedicated in 1889. It was named a National Historic Landmark in 2012.

Photoraph by Jim, the Photographer on Flickr. CC BY 2.0.

Fonthill Castle in Doylestown

The Fonthill Castle, which was built between 1908 and 1812, is a mix of Medieval, Gothic and Byzantine architectural styles, according to the Mercer Museum & Fonthill Castle's website. It's notable for being an early example of poured reinforced concrete.

Henry Chapman Mercer designed the castle The archaeologist, scholar and antiquarian lived in the building but also used it to show off his collection of tiles and prints.

Photograph by Kristine Paulus on Flickr. CC BY 2.0.

Grey Towers in Milford

Where: You can find the towers at 122 Old Owego Turnpike in Milford, according to its website.

James and Mary Pinchot built the Grey Towers in 1886 as a summer retreat, according to its website. Gifford Pinchot, their eldest son and the first Chief of the U.S. Forest Service and two-term Pennsylvania Governor, later lived in the building.

Gifford Bryce Pinchot, Gifford Pinchot's son, and his family later donated the Grey Towers and its surrounding 102 acres to the U.S. Forest Service, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

M. Carey Thomas Library in Bryn Mawr

Where: The library can be found on the campus of Bryn Mawr College at 101 N. Merion Ave. in Bryn Mawr, according to its website.

The M. Carey Thomas Library was built 1907 on the Bryn Mawr College campus, according to the National Register of Historic Places registration form for the building on Bryn Mawr College's website. The stone building encloses a quadrangle on three sides. Its main building has a "three-story stack with accommodations for 88,000 volumes." Above this stack area is a great hall that has a high ceiling with lead-paned windows, which gives it a "cathedral-like effect."

Architect Walter Cope designed the building.

Photograph by Montgomery County Planning Commission on Flickr. CC BY-SA 2.0.

Woodmont in Gladwyne

Where: The building is located at 1622 Spring Mill Rd. in Gladwyne, according a document on the National Park Service's website.

The 73-acre Woodmont property has a three-story stone manor house, according to the National Park Service. The house is described as being “transitional between the late Gothic and the French Renaissance styles.”

“Seen from the south, the house is an assembly of steep gabled and hipped roof volumes, and a boldly projecting porte cochere, all of which are dominated by the high pyramidal roof that expresses the Great Hall at the center of the plan,” according to the National Park.

Palace Mission Inc. of the Peace Mission Movement owns and operates the property, which is a National Historic Landmark.

The University of Pennsylvania's Psi Upsilon Fraternity building in Philadelphia

Where: The building is located at 250 S. 36th St. in Philadelphia, according to its website.

The Psi Upsilon Fraternity Building at the University of Pennsylvania is a mid-century Victorian suburban Gothic mansion, according to its website. Its design adapts the towers details of Philadelphia architects Walter Cope and John Stewardson’s academic Gothic.

Photograph by Mihai Bojin on Flickr. CC BY 2.0.

The Masonic Temple in Philadelphia

Where: The temple is located at 1 N. Broad St. in Philadelphia, according to its website.

The Masonic Temple was built 1873 across the street from City Hall in Philadelphia, according to its website. It has a Norman cathedral-like exterior but adopts a number of different styles for its interior, according to Visit Philadelphia.

Architect James Windrim designed the building, which was constructed over five years for a total of $1.6 million. Artist George Herzog decorated the inside of the building, a process which took nearly 20 years.

A tour of of Cellblock 3, also called the Hospital Block at Eastern State Penitentiary in Philadelphia. Cellblock 3 has captivated visitors' imaginations since the penitentiary opened as a museum more than 20 years ago. Opportunities to step past the head gate, ornamented with its iconic red cross, have been rare. The few hardhat tours offered over the years filled to capacity, affirming visitors' strong interest in seeing this eerie and fascinating space. A series of stabilization projects has finally made it possible for visitors to safely enter the long-abandoned medical wing. Beginning May 5, 15-minute guided tours will be offered several times a day. Visitors will explore the corridor of Cellblock 3 and learn more about this unusually well equipped prison hospital. They will see Eastern State's operating room, laboratories, pharmacy, X-ray lab, hydrotherapy rooms, psychiatric department, and a solarium for treating tuberculosis patients. A number of medical artifacts remain in place, despite decades of abandonment and decay. (Sean Simmers / PennLive.com. April 26, 2017)

Eastern State Penitentiary in Philadelphia

Where: The prison is located near the intersection at 22nd Street and Fairmount Avenue in Philadelphia, according to Visit Philadelphia's website.

The Eastern State Penitentiary is described as having "soaring, castle-like Gothic architecture," according to Visit Philadelphia. Ever since it was first opened in 1829, the 11-acre prison has been a model for other prisons throughout the world. About 300 on four continents base their design on the Eastern State Penitentiary's "wagon-wheel floor plan."

The prison was abandoned in 1971 but has since been designated as a National Historic Landmark. It once held notable criminals, such as the gangster Al Capone.

To see more photographs, visit this photo gallery.

Photograph by Tim Engleman on Flickr. CC BY-SA 2.0.

Allegheny County Courthouse and Jail in Pittsburgh

The Allegheny County Courthouse and Jail is described as having the "classic symmetry of the Renaissance, with Romanesque details, including Syrian arches, Byzantine Capitals, late French Gothic dormer windows and French Renaissance roofs," according to Allegheny County's website. One of the complex's most impressive features is its tower, which rises more than 229 feet.

Boston architect Henry Hobson Richardson designed the Allegheny County Courthouse and Jail complex in 1883, which was built between 1884 and 1888. The jail was closed in 1995 and converted into the juvenile and home sections for the Common Pleas Court.

Bowman's Castle in Brownsville

Where: The building is located near the intersection of Front and Second streets in Brownsville, according to the National Park Service.

Bowman's Castle, which is also known as the Nemacolin Castle, was constructed in stages from 1789 through to 1900, according to the National Park Service. Some of its most notable features include battlements on its three-story story, bracketed cornices and a glass-enclosed conservatory

Jacob Bowman originally built it as a home and trading post, making it “an important commercial enterprise on Pennsylvania’s frontier.”

Photograph by Todd Van Hoosear on Flickr. CC BY-SA 2.0.

Stokesay Castle in Reading

Where: The castle is located at 141 Stokesay Castle Lane in Reading, according to its website.

The Stokesay Castle was built in 1931, according to its website. The building was inspired by a 13th-century English castle of the same name. It had vaulted cathedral ceilings, hand-carved beams and leaded windows.

The Hiester family used it as a vacation home until 1956, according to its website. It was then converted into a restaurant in the 1970s, which closed down in 2007. Jack Gulati later restored the property in 2009. Today, the Stokesay castle has a fine dining restaurant and a pub. It is also a wedding venue.

Photograph by Tim Engleman on Flickr. CC BY-SA 2.0.

Glencairn Museum in Bryn Athyn

Where: The museum is located at 1001 Cathedral Road in Bryn Athyn, according to its website.

The Glencairn was built between 1928 and 1939, according to its website. Its style is based on medieval Romanesque architecture.

Raymond Pitcairn, Mildred Glenn and their children made their home in the building at first. It’s now the a museum of religious art and history.

The Sibley mansion in Franklin

Where: The mansion is located at 870 River Ridge Rd. in Franklin.

The Sibley mansion was constructed in 1913 following the French Provincial style, according to the Titusville Herald. It has 33 rooms, including six bedrooms.

Joseph Sibley resided in the property for 25 years. Life Ministries currently owns and conducts tours of the property.

The Old Cumberland County Prison in Carlisle

Where: The prison is near the intersection of East High and Bedford streets in Carlisle, according to the Cumberland County Historical Society.

Philadelphia architect Edward Haviland designed the "castle-like" Old Cumberland County Prison, which was in operation from 1854 through to 1984, according to Visit Cumberland Valley.

The Lancaster County Prison in Lancaster

Where: The prison is located at 625 E. King St. in Lancaster.

The Lancaster County Prison was opened in 1851, according to Franklin & Marshall College's website. Philadelphia architect John Haviland designed the building to resemble a castle in Lancashire, England. It was also modelled after the "penitentiary" prison style, like the Eastern Penitentiary Prison in Philadelphia.

Fisher Fine Arts Library in Philadelphia

Where: The building is located 220 S. 34th St. in Philadelphia, according to its website.

The eight-story Fisher Fine Arts Library was built in 1890, according to the university's website. Philadelphia architect Frank Furness designed the building at the University of Pennsylvania, bringing together aspects of a cathedral and a railroad station. It had 65,026 square feet of space.

Bradford Armory Building in Bradford

Where: The building is located at 28 Barbour St. in Bradford, according to the National Park Service.

The Bradford Armory building was built in 1912, according to the National Park Service. It's a yellow brick building influenced by the Romanesque style. Its features include a "crenelated parapet with corbeling, double hung sash windows and decorative stonework, including a watr table, coping, sills and lintels."

Photograph by Dr. Boli on Flickr. CC BY 2.0.

Westinghouse Castle in Wilmerding

Where: The castle is located at 325 Commerce St. in Wilmerding.

Frederick J. Osterling, a Pittsburgh architect, designed the original structure in the 1890s, according to TribLive. Benno Janssen, another Pittsburgh architect, built its secondary part in the 1920s.

John Graf, its current owner, plans to convert the structure to include 35 guest suites, three ballrooms. facilities for “corporate-style retreats,” a restaurant and a gaming room.

Looking for more sights around Pennsylvania? Then check out these stories.
